Award.AwardTitle: Integrated STEM and Computing Learning in Formal and Informal Settings for Kindergarten to Grade 2

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
a result, the STEM+Computing Partnership (STEM+C) program seeks to integrate the use of computational approaches in K-12 STEM teaching and learning and understand how this integration can improve STEM learning, engagement, and persistence. Computational Thinking (CT) is a relatively new educational focus and a clear need for learners as a 21st century skill. This proposal tackles this challenging new area for young learners, an area greatly in need of research and learning materials. The Principal Investigators will develop and implement integrated STEM+C museum exhibits and integrate CT in their existing engineering design based PictureSTEM curriculum for K-2 students. They will also pilot assessments of the CT components of the PictureSTEM curriculum. This work will make a unique contribution to the available STEM+C learning materials and assessments. There are few such materials for the kindergarten to second grade (K-2) population they will work with. They will research the effects of the curriculum and the exhibits with a mixed methods approach. First, they will collect observational data and conduct case studies to discover the important elements of an integrated STEM+C experience in both the formal in-school setting with the curriculum and in the informal out-of-school setting with families interacting with the museum exhibits. This work will provide a novel way to understand the important question of how in- and out-of-school experiences contribute to the development of STEM and CT thinking and learning. Finally, they will collect data from all participants to discover the ways that their activities lead to increases in STEM+C knowledge and interest.

The Principal Investigators will build on an integrated STEM curriculum by integrating CT and develop integrated museum exhibits. They base both activities on engineering design implemented through challenge based programming activities. They will research and/or develop assessments of both STEM+C integrated thinking and CT. Their research strategy combines Design Based Research and quantitative assessment of the effectiveness of the materials for learning CT. In the first two years of their study, they will engage in iterations on the design of the curriculum and the exhibits based on observation and case-study data. There will be 16 cases that draw from each grade level and involve data collection for the case student in both schools and museums. They will also use this work to illuminate what integrated STEM+C thinking and learning looks like across formal and informal learning environments. Based in some part on what they discover in this first phase, they will conduct the quantitative assessments with all (or at least most) students participating in the study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

 

Overview

Integrating science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) subjects in pre-college settings is seen as critical in providing opportunities for children to develop knowledge, skills, and interests in these subjects and the associated critical thinking skills. More recently computational thinking (CT) has been called out as an equally important topic to emphasize among pre-college students. However, much of the research and development work that has been done to promote CT education has focused on learners that are 3rd grade or older. This project was one of the first to focus on young learners in K-2nd grade. The research from this project provides rich descriptions of what it looks like for young children to engage in computational thinking in three different contexts: schools, homeschool settings, and at a science center. A major outcome of the project was the definitions and descriptions of computational thinking for K-2nd grade-aged children. In this project, computational thinking was conceptualized as both a problem-solving process and as a set of distinct but interrelated activities. We particularly focused on abstraction, problem decomposition, algorithms & procedures, and troubleshooting/debugging.

 

Curriculum

The project also resulted in curricular modules for K, 1st and 2nd grade classrooms that are research-based and iteratively refined by teams of researchers and teachers. The curricular modules are freely available and can provide a launching point for other researchers and educators interested in studying STEM+C amongst this age group. The PictureSTEM curriculum integrates science, engineering, mathematics, literacy and computational thinking for K-2 learners through a series of lessons, 1 introductory lesson and 6 paired literacy and STEM+C lessons, for a total of 13 lessons that are implemented in 30-60 minute class sessions. The curriculum is available on the PictureSTEM.org website, and each unit includes orientation materials for teachers, standards alignment (to NGSS, CCSS - Math, CCSS - English/Language Arts, CSTA standards, and Indiana state standards), lesson summaries, unit overviews, materials lists, and detailed description of each lesson. We video-recorded 43 of the K-2nd grade classrooms that used this curriculum to investigate how children engaged in STEM+literacy+CT. The curriculum can be fournd at http://picturestem.org/

 

Informal Learning Environments

Another core part of the project was the development of resources for informal learning environments. In collaboration with the Purdue Exhibit Design Center, we developed a “Computing for the Critters” exhibit for a small science center in Indiana. Major components of the exhibit include a play structure that allows children to imagine themselves as a robot delivering medicine to animals before they interact with a computer game that prompts them to create “code” (a sequence of directions) to help the robot deliver medicine to animals. We conducted research on families’ interactions with each other and the exhibit to investigate how children engage in computational thinking and engineering design in the science center setting. Prior to the development of the “Computing for the Critters” exhibit, we developed activities that families could do together using materials already present at the science center. This allowed us to conduct initial research on family CT engagement, which informed the exhibit development process. A total of 20 families participated in our studies of CT in informal settings, and 13 of the children from these families also participated in the school-based study. We were able to further investigate how/if children made connections between the school and science center activities when one of our partner teachers brought her class to the science center for a field trip.

 

Diversity and Inclusion

Finally, throughout the project broadening participation was a critical concern. We approached this by: 1) developing activities that center people or animals and their needs, 2) developing activities to help children connect their own interests with engineering, and 3) including images of diverse people in the exhibit. Providing contexts that center people or animals and their needs helps children to understand how engineering can be socially-relevant, provides opportunities for children to practice developing an understanding of a problem in addition to finding a solution to the problem, and helps children develop human-centered design skills. In our “Make an Engineer” activity, children (and youth and adults) are able to connect their own interests to engineering and problems engineers could work on. Similarly, many of our activities focus on animals, as pets and animals are a common area of interest for K-2nd grade aged children. Finally, our exhibit contains images of children and adults who are diverse in terms of race, ethnicity, gender, and ability. Our “Make an Engineer”, “Puppy Playground” and “Cozmo the Ambulance” activities can be found on our website, https://engineering.purdue.edu/INSPIRE/Resources.
